From: Darren Izzard <zysyshelp@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Another note on activation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=197251447; y=er7NqbAOBGRuoPhzdUdin9lZwgiNLt-9mmtZYXNlsp2N8g
X-Yahoo-Profile: zysyshelp

Hi Steve -

>Given that, then how could such a network possibly have any memory (or 
>time delay)?

Each time the network was evaluated, each node would look at its 
inputs, and after doing the requisite maths, pass it to its outputs.

So, let's say a "1" is at the input of the delayline at a given timestep:

1-n-n-n-n

where "n" is undefined. I am of course ignoring the influence of 
weights here. After one timestep, we get:-

x-1-n-n-n

After another, we get:-

y-x-1-n-n

etc. etc.

Also bear in mind that with the "roving eye" the inputs do change 
between each evaluation. The network itself returns instructions to 
the test loop saying "move my window left" or "move my window up" etc. 
until it eventually returns one saying, "I've seen enough and I know 
what the shape is."

It's important to remember that the network is only reset/cleared at 
the beginning of a test on a particular shape, and during that test 
the repeated evaluations don't include a reset.

To pull this together, you'd get a loop along the following likes:-

---
Reset network.
Choose random shape and random location for window.
Set timesteps to 0.
Do
   Evaluate network.
   If result command is "move window", then move window
Until result command is "stop" OR timesteps>maximum
If timesteps>maximum then mark network as failure.
If result command is "stop" then check whether reported shape is correct.
---

I hope that clarifies it.

So you're correct that propagation through the network is not complete 
at each timestep. But I don't see why you claim NEAT cannot converge 
under these circumstances.

--Darren
